publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... you have gone (down), offering this life of discipline, ... Law ...
... to be the hope. 1 || Thereupon, Metrak, as the God Brahmā, ... (the rank of) Buddha
... in the middle of an immense crowd of gods, with Cintāmaṇi-jewels,
... seated on the throne adorned with lions and decorated with jewels, ... the Law
... the venerable Metrak, having been taught by seeing the bodies of Buddhas in ... great eons,
... this one is the Buddha-god the teacher! At the same time, however, having recalled the promise made to Bādhari the Brahmin, joyfully
... See, you good ones! || In the Bahudantāk [tune] || Without any doubt, this one is the Buddha-god the teacher: multicolored (is) his body hair; (there is) the uṣṇīṣa (on the top of his head);
... his eyes (are) blue; (he has) a Brahmā-like voice; wide and supple (is) his tongue; having attained distinctions of tastes; his jaws (are) like those of a lion;
... (he is) broad with respect to his well-formed shoulders; he is tall, with a straight(?) body; he is sculptured as it were between his shoulders; seven prominent [places]; fine (skin);
... with (upright) body-hair; the mark (of the) pudendum; well-rounded (is) his body; without bending (his body), his knees can be reached; (like those of) the aiṇeya-deer
... webs between his fingers; soft (are) his palms and the underside of his feet; his heels (are) slender and beautiful; (his palms and the underside of his feet are) decorated with the wheel mark;
... those 32 great marks (appear) in their entirety, fully developed, surely excellent and absolutely complete.
... indeed, surely indeed this one is the Buddha-god the teacher. Oh what an appearance
... excellent. Thereupon, the brahmin youths, remembering the promise made to Bādhari the Brahmin,
... The brahmin youth (Tiṣya) poses only in his mind (the question): Our teacher, Bādhari,
... they intend to ask. Why (do) I not (with) firmness(?)

p.note: The commentary is adapted from 117-8.
MaitrHami 2, 11-12
This fragment contains part of the second act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami II, 11a14-12a22. See also 195-6.
The text immediately continues on .
The translation and following commentary are adapted from 117-8.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a17ff., and the last line of this leaf corresponds roughly to MaitrHami 2, 12 a22ff. (for the Uy. references, cf. 18).
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a21ff.
The form -pälkās may be the accusative plural of a Bahuvrīhi compound in -pälk, but the segmentation remains uncertain.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a30.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 b2-3.

Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 b7ff. bahudantākaṃ: presumably two stanzas of 4 x 25 (5/5/8/7 or 7/8) syllables. [[The 32 marks of the Buddha]] (mahāpuruṣa-lakṣaṇa) are in the following not given in the same order as before (see verso and recto), and they are often formulated more briefly. The number of the mark in the preceding list is given in square brackets, and is followed by the Sanskrit term according to the Mahāvyutpatti. yok refers to mark no. 1, absent in the former catalogue; it corresponds to an “additional mark” and to a minor mark (anuvyañjana), as bhramarasadṛśakeśaḥ Mvy 342 (74).
uṣṇir mrācaṃ refers to mark no. 2 [31]: uṣṇīṣaśiraskatā.

aśäṃ refers to mark no. 5 [29]: abhinīlanetragopakṣmā.The beginning of the line contained the marks nos. 3 [32] and 4 [30]. wak refers to mark no. 6 [28]: brahmasvaraḥ. käntu refers to mark no. 7 [27]: prabhūtatanujihvaḥ. tspokṣinās refers to mark no. 8 [26]: rasarasāgratā. The form wākmats is a mistake in the manuscript; read wākmant, as in : a6; cf. : a4?
śanweṃ refers to mark no. 9 [25]: siṃhahanuḥ. The marks nos. 10 [24], 11 [21], 12 [22], 13 [23], concerning the teeth, are lost in the following lacuna.

wärts refers to mark no. 14 [20]: susaṃvṛttaskandhaḥ; both TA worku and woru (as in : a2) would seem to be genuine forms. kapśño refers to mark no. 15 [19]: bṛhadṛjukāyaḥ. esnaṃ refers to mark no. 16 [17]: citāntarāṃsaḥ. paplätkunt refers to mark no. 17 [16]: saptotsadaḥ.
ly_käly^ä\: reading corrected after 281.
yats (restoration after 281) refers to mark no. 18 [15]: sūkṣmasuvarṇacchaviḥ. The mark no. 19 [13] is lost in the following lacuna.

yokum refers to mark no. 20 [12]: ūrdhvāgraromaḥ. ṣotre refers to mark no. 21 [10]: kośagatavastiguhyaḥ. kapśañi refers to mark no. 22 [11]: nyagrodhaparimaṇḍalaḥ. tkālune refers to mark no. 23 [9]: sthitānavanatapralambabāhutā. ainey is the beginning of mark no. 24 [8]: aiṇeyajaṅghaḥ. The mark no. 25 [7] was also in the next line.
ainey^ä\: reading corrected after 281.
prārwaṃ refers to mark no. 26 [6]: jālāvanaddhahastapādaḥ. peṃ refers to mark no. 27 [5]: mṛdutaruṇahastapādatalaḥ. kukäṃ refers to mark no. 28 [4]: āyatapādapārṣṇiḥ.
yetunt refers to mark no. 29 [2]: cakrāṅkitahastapādatalaḥ. The last mark, no. 30 [1] was listed at the end of the same pāda.

taryāk we pi: actually, this catalogue contained only 30 marks, which are given without number. One mark (no. 1) has been added, and three marks of the former list [nos. 3, 14, 18] have been merged with closely related marks, respectively nos. 26 [6], 18 [15], 15 [19].
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a5-6.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a12ff.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a16-17.

list.item: a1 /// [p]·saṃ ye_t\ : saṃvarṣiṃ ca_m\ śo_l\ eṣan_t _m_a- a2 /// (·)[ma]ṅk na_s_a_l\ : 1 || _t_m_a_ṣ _s_am metrakṣi bra_m\ ñ_kä_t\ putti- a3 /// – [_p_a]lkā_s _s_a_m\ sne yär_m\ ñäkci kropaṃ ywārckā cindāmaṇisyo a4 /// ·[_t](\) yetwesyo yetun_t\ wāmpun_t\ śiś_k_asyo āsānā lmon_t\ _m_a- a5 /// [l]ps·(·) ptāñäktaśśi kapśiṃñā_s _p_alkāluneyaṃ āklye yāmu āṣāni_k\ me- a6 /// ñ_k_a_t\ _k_aṣṣi _s_a_s\ : ṣñikek nu bādhari_s\ brāmne plā_k_a_m\ opyācä\ klo_r_a_ṣ wso- a7 /// ·[k]·[c] krañcśä\ || bahudantākaṃ || sne sañce wätkā_lt_s\ ptāñ_k_a_t _k_aṣṣi _s_a_s\ rājavartt yo_k\ uṣṇi- a8 /// [k]āñä\ aśäṃ brahmasvar wa_k\ wärt_s\ knuṃt_s\ _k_antu yomu wākmat_s\ tspokṣinā_s\ śiśkināñ śa- b1 /// su worku esnaṃ wärt_s\ : tsopat_s\ smak kapśño tsātsekw oky esnaṃ _ṣ_p_at pa_p_l_atkun_t\ ly_kälyä\ b2 /// k[u]_m\ gośogat\ ṣotre parimaṇḍa_l\ sam kapśañi mā nmo kanweṃ tkālune : aineyä\ b3 /// piñä\ prārwaṃ wlyepaṃ āleṃ śalaṃ peṃ : aṣu_k\ krañśä\ ku_k_aṃ cāk_r_a lakṣaṇyo yetu- b4 /// [n]yo : [ta]ryāk we pi toṣ śāwaṃ ṣotreytu ypic pa_p_l_atkun_t\ wätkā_lt_s\ wākmtsaṃ puk sa- b5 /// ·[äṣ]pā wätkā_lt_s\ wäṣpā ptāñ_k_a_t _k_aṣṣi _s_a_s\ • ote _t_apreṃ lkālune- b6 /// [r] ·[ā]kmat_s\ • _t_m_aṣ cem manarkāñä\ bādharis prāmne plā_k_a_m\ opyā- b7 /// manar_k\ _p_alskaṃn at_s\ ya_t_ar wa_s_aṃ _upādhyā bādhari b8 /// pra_k_assi _p_aknāsant_r_a • k_uyal mā _n_aṣ wätkā-

The commentary is adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 117-8.

a3. The form -pälkās may be the accusative plural of a Bahuvrīhi compound in -pälk, but the segmentation remains uncertain.

a1. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a17ff., and the last line of this leaf corresponds roughly to MaitrHami 2, 12 a22ff. (for the Uy. references, cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18).

a2. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a21ff.

a5. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 a30.

a6. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 b2-3.

a7. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 11 b7ff. bahudantākaṃ: presumably two stanzas of 4 x 25 (5/5/8/7 or 7/8) syllables. [[The 32 marks of the Buddha]] (mahāpuruṣa-lakṣaṇa) are in the following not given in the same order as before (see [[YQ II.4]] verso and [[YQ II.5]] recto), and they are often formulated more briefly. The number of the mark in the preceding list is given in square brackets, and is followed by the Sanskrit term according to the Mahāvyutpatti. yok refers to mark no. 1, absent in the former catalogue; it corresponds to an “additional mark” and to a minor mark (anuvyañjana), as bhramarasadṛśakeśaḥ Mvy 342 (74).

a7-8. uṣṇir mrācaṃ refers to mark no. 2 [31]: uṣṇīṣaśiraskatā.

a8. aśäṃ refers to mark no. 5 [29]: abhinīlanetragopakṣmā.The beginning of the line contained the marks nos. 3 [32] and 4 [30]. wak refers to mark no. 6 [28]: brahmasvaraḥ. käntu refers to mark no. 7 [27]: prabhūtatanujihvaḥ. tspokṣinās refers to mark no. 8 [26]: rasarasāgratā. The form wākmats is a mistake in the manuscript; read wākmant, as in [[A 213]]: a6; cf. [[YQ II.5]]: a4?

a8, b1. śanweṃ refers to mark no. 9 [25]: siṃhahanuḥ. The marks nos. 10 [24], 11 [21], 12 [22], 13 [23], concerning the teeth, are lost in the following lacuna.

b1. wärts refers to mark no. 14 [20]: susaṃvṛttaskandhaḥ; both TA worku and woru (as in [[YQ II.5]]: a2) would seem to be genuine forms. kapśño refers to mark no. 15 [19]: bṛhadṛjukāyaḥ. esnaṃ refers to mark no. 16 [17]: citāntarāṃsaḥ. paplätkunt refers to mark no. 17 [16]: saptotsadaḥ.

b1. ly_käly^ä\: reading corrected after [[Schmidt KT 1999b]]: 281.

b1-2. yats (restoration after [[Schmidt KT 1999b]]: 281) refers to mark no. 18 [15]: sūkṣmasuvarṇacchaviḥ. The mark no. 19 [13] is lost in the following lacuna.

b2. yokum refers to mark no. 20 [12]: ūrdhvāgraromaḥ. ṣotre refers to mark no. 21 [10]: kośagatavastiguhyaḥ. kapśañi refers to mark no. 22 [11]: nyagrodhaparimaṇḍalaḥ. tkālune refers to mark no. 23 [9]: sthitānavanatapralambabāhutā. ainey is the beginning of mark no. 24 [8]: aiṇeyajaṅghaḥ. The mark no. 25 [7] was also in the next line.

b2. ainey^ä\: reading corrected after [[Schmidt KT 1999b]]: 281.

b3. prārwaṃ refers to mark no. 26 [6]: jālāvanaddhahastapādaḥ. peṃ refers to mark no. 27 [5]: mṛdutaruṇahastapādatalaḥ. kukäṃ refers to mark no. 28 [4]: āyatapādapārṣṇiḥ.

b3-4. yetunt refers to mark no. 29 [2]: cakrāṅkitahastapādatalaḥ. The last mark, no. 30 [1] was listed at the end of the same pāda.

b4. taryāk we pi: actually, this catalogue contained only 30 marks, which are given without number. One mark (no. 1) has been added, and three marks of the former list [nos. 3, 14, 18] have been merged with closely related marks, respectively nos. 26 [6], 18 [15], 15 [19].

b5. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a5-6.

b6. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a12ff.

b7. Cf. MaitrHami 2, 12 a16-17.

a1 ... you have gone (down), offering this life of discipline, ... Law ... a2 ... to be the hope. 1 || Thereupon, Metrak, as the God Brahmā, ... (the rank of) Buddha a3 ... in the middle of an immense crowd of gods, with Cintāmaṇi-jewels, a4 ... seated on the throne adorned with lions and decorated with jewels, ... the Law a5 ... the venerable Metrak, having been taught by seeing the bodies of Buddhas in ... great eons, a6 ... this one is the Buddha-god the teacher! At the same time, however, having recalled the promise made to Bādhari the Brahmin, joyfully a7 ... See, you good ones! || In the Bahudantāk [tune] || Without any doubt, this one is the Buddha-god the teacher: multicolored (is) his body hair; (there is) the uṣṇīṣa (on the top of his head); a8 ... his eyes (are) blue; (he has) a Brahmā-like voice; wide and supple (is) his tongue; having attained distinctions of tastes; his jaws (are) like those of a lion; b1 ... (he is) broad with respect to his well-formed shoulders; he is tall, with a straight(?) body; he is sculptured as it were between his shoulders; seven prominent [places]; fine (skin); b2 ... with (upright) body-hair; the mark (of the) pudendum; well-rounded (is) his body; without bending (his body), his knees can be reached; (like those of) the aiṇeya-deer b3 ... webs between his fingers; soft (are) his palms and the underside of his feet; his heels (are) slender and beautiful; (his palms and the underside of his feet are) decorated with the wheel mark; b4 ... those 32 great marks (appear) in their entirety, fully developed, surely excellent and absolutely complete. b5 ... indeed, surely indeed this one is the Buddha-god the teacher. Oh what an appearance b6 ... excellent. Thereupon, the brahmin youths, remembering the promise made to Bādhari the Brahmin, b7 ... The brahmin youth (Tiṣya) poses only in his mind (the question): Our teacher, Bādhari, b8 ... they intend to ask. Why (do) I not (with) firmness(?)

This fragment contains part of the second act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami II, 11a14-12a22. See also [[Pinault 1999]]: 195-6.

The text immediately continues on [[YQ II.11]].

The translation and following commentary are adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 117-8.
b2, translation above = [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 115; [[Carling, DThTA]]: 123 translates “without bending himself [he has] the capacity of touching his two knees” (TI)

a1 /// p(o)saṃ yet : saṃvarṣiṃ cam śol eṣant märkampalṣiṃ|mä|(rkampalṣiṃ) a2 /// (pär)maṅk nasäl : 1 || tmäṣ säm metrakṣi bram ñkät puttiśparäṃ|putti|(śparäṃ) a3 /// – pälkās säm sne yärm ñäkci kropaṃ ywārckā cindāmaṇisyo a4 /// ·(n)t yetwesyo yetunt wāmpunt śiśkäsyo āsānā lmont märkampal|mä|(rkampal) a5 /// (mahāka)lps(aṃ) ptāñäktaśśi kapśiṃñās pälkāluneyaṃ āklye yāmu āṣānik metrak|me|(trak) a6 /// (ptā)ñkät käṣṣi säs : ṣñikek_(TA)|ṣñikek nu bādharis brāmne plākäm opyāc kloräṣ wsokoneyo|wso|(koneyo) a7 /// (päl)k(ā)c krañcś || bahudantākaṃ || # sne sañce wätkālts ; ptāñkät käṣṣi säs ; rājavartt yok , uṣṇir|uṣṇi|(r) a8 (mrācaṃ) ; %7 #1a %5 /// ; (tseṃ yo)kāñ aśäṃ ; brahmasvar_(TA)|brahmasvar wak , wärts knuṃts käntu ; yomu wākmats , tspokṣinās #1b śiśkināñ śanweṃ|śa|(nweṃ) b1 ; %13 /// ; (kā)su worku , esnaṃ wärts : #1c tsopats smak kapśño ; tsātsekw oky esnaṃ ; ṣpät paplätkunt , lykäly b2 (yats) %9 #1d %3 /// (yo)kum ; gośogat ṣotre ; parimaṇḍal , sam kapśañi ; mā nmo kanweṃ , tkālune : #2a ainey b3 %12 /// , (so)piñ prārwaṃ ; wlyepaṃ āleṃ , śalaṃ peṃ : #2b aṣuk krañś kukäṃ ; cākrä lakṣaṇyo ; yetunt|yetu|(nt) b4 %12 /// nyo : #2c taryāk we pi toṣ ; śāwaṃ ṣotreytu ; ypic paplätkunt , wätkālts wākmtsaṃ ; puk salu|sa|(lu) b5 %4 #2d /// (w)äṣpā wätkālts wäṣpā ptāñkät käṣṣi säs • ote täpreṃ lkāluneyo|lkālune|(yo) b6 /// r (w)ākmats • tmäṣ cem manarkāñ bādharis prāmne plākäm opyāc|opyā|(c) b7 (kloräṣ) /// manark pälskaṃn ats yatär wasäṃ _upādhyā bādhari b8 /// prakässi päknāsanträ • k_uyal mā näṣ wätkāltsuneyo|wätkā|(ltsuneyo)

div.p: , translation above = <citedRange>115</citedRange></bibl>; <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>123</citedRange></bibl> translates “without bending himself [he has] the capacity of touching his two knees” (TI)</p></project_comment>
